*[Bug 18648] tools::startDynamicHelp(): Can get stuck in "server could not be started on an earlier attempt" state*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18648>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |INVALID

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
From my reading of the code, the current behavior was intentional. It wasn't
documented, either, so I've documented it now to avoid potential further
confusion.

One can change the option "help_type" between "html" and something else within
an R session, and this is the intended interface for most users. The low-level
function startDynamicHelp() can be used to stop the server during an R session,
but users shouldn't normally need to call this directly.

Well, I think I'd like to agree what you said in comment #12,
and then be done with it. It *is* correct :

```
> rep(1:3,times = 1:3 , each = 0)
Error in rep(1:3, times = 1:3, each = 0) : 
  invalid 'times' argument, given the value of 'each'
> 
```
as indeed, without a `times` argument, with `times = 1` or `times = 0`,  `each
= 0`  works,  in all cases returning `integer(0)`.

(Being back from vacations), I will add some regression tests, and commit then,
as I really don't want us spend more time to find the perfect message in all
cases.  After all it *is* a user error, they get an error with a reasonable
message and then should fix their wrong code, by thinking.

*[Bug 18715] Package built for more recent versions of R library()*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18715>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
         Resolution|---                         |INVALID
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
This warning is displayed also on other platforms, not only on Windows. When
the difference is only in the patch version (the "z" of "x.y.z"), if everything
goes well and nobody made a mistake, it typically shouldn't matter these days.
But, packages are not tested on older versions of R than they are built on, so,
there is some risk. With changes in the major or minor version ("x" or "y" in
"x.y.z"), the risk of breakage is very high.

To be on the safe side and take advantage of all the CRAN testing, it is really
better to upgrade R in such a case. So, I think the warning should stay, with
the same visibility, even for the patch version. Also, given that the warning
has been displayed in the past, removing it could cause undesirable confusion
(what if others are really using it as a reminder there is a newer version, and
that they can update).

<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18748>

--- Comment #2 from Ivan Krylov (<mailto:ikrylov@disroot.org|ikrylov@disroot.org>) ---
Thank you very much! One small typo:

```
Index: src/main/array.c
===================================================================
--- src/main/array.c    (revision 88641)
+++ src/main/array.c    (working copy)
@@ -164,7 +164,7 @@
            warning(_("non-empty data for zero-extent matrix"));
     }

-#ifndef LONG_VECTOR_SUPPORT
+#ifdef LONG_VECTOR_SUPPORT
     if ((double)nr * (double)nc > R_XLEN_T_MAX)
        error(_("too many elements specified"));
 #else
```

Otherwise `matrix(raw(), nrow = 2^16, ncol = 2^16)` immediately complains on a
64-bit system instead of allocating 4 GiB of zeros.
